docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Dick Cheney and Senator John Edwards campaigned on starkly different themes in the same city on Monday, with Mr. Cheney suggesting that President Bill Clinton and even President Ronald Reagan were soft on terrorists, while Mr. Edwards called President Bush a failure on pocketbook concerns like jobs and health care. With the race entering its final phase, the Republican and Democratic vice-presidential candidates ramped up their arguments on the issues they consider their own.

headline.main: Cheney's Praise of Bush Takes a Dig at Clinton (and Reagan)

docs.abstract: Republican and Democratic vice-presidential candidates, appearing in St Paul, Minn, ramp up their arguments on issues they consider their own; Vice Pres Cheney blames former Pres Clinton and even former Pres Reagan for teaching terrorists they could strike at America with 'relative impunity' and could 'change our policy'; cites terrorist attacks during Reagan and Clinton administrations; contrasts this with actions Pres Bush took after 9/11 attacks; Sen John Edwards calls Pres Bush failure on pocketbook concerns like jobs and health care; lists statistics that speak of anxiety many Americans are feeling about their jobs (M)
docs.snippet: Vice President Dick Cheney suggested that former presidents were soft on terrorists, while Senator John Edwards called President Bush a failure on jobs and health care.

byline.original: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and RICK LYMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton, a cigar-smoking workaholic whose family history of heart disease and passion for junk food had set him up for a heart attack in the near future, underwent successful quadruple coronary bypass surgery yesterday at a hospital in New York, his doctors said. They said Mr. Clinton was resting comfortably afterward and was expected to make a complete recovery.

headline.main: Clinton Is Given Bypass Surgery For 4 Arteries

docs.abstract: Former Pres Clinton undergoes successful quadruple coronary bypass surgery at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan; doctors say he is resting comfortably afterward and is expected to make complete recovery; four-hour open-heart procedure by team of surgeons is led by Dr Craig R Smith, hospital's chief of cardio-thoracic surgery; Dr Allan Schwartz, hospital's chief of cardiology, says that without bypass surgery, there was 'substantial likelihood' that Clinton would have had serious heart attack in near future; Schwartz, Smith and other doctors attending post-operation press conference say that Clinton's heart muscle is strong and with proper diet and other precautions he could resume active life within weeks and could look forward to normal lifespan; he turned 58 on Aug 19; 45,000 calls, letters and messages of support pour into hospital and to Web site; Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton and daughter Chelsea express gratitude to medical team and staff at hospital; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Former President Bill Clinton, a workaholic with a passion for junk food, underwent successful quadruple bypass surgery.

byline.original: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN and LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: The year's big drug-industry merger may turn out to be about using marketing muscle to fight fat. In April, when the French drug company Sanofi-Synthélabo vanquished all other players with a long-shot takeover bid for a much larger French-German rival, Aventis, many commentators focused on the role of politicians in Paris.

headline.main: Diet Pill Was a Driving Force in a French Drug Merger

docs.abstract: French drug company Sanofi-Synthelabo's acquisition of French-German rival Aventis linked to Sanofi's new drug rimonabant, which will be marketed as Acomplia, that fights obesity and smoking; drug was in Sanofi's pipeline long before merger of company, now called Sanofi-Aventis; analysts and doctors say drug could become one of industry's once-in-a-decade blockbusters; Sanofi plans to file for regulatory approval early next year in US and Europe; hopes to put drug on market in 2006; Sanofi needed Aventis's powerful sales force to market drug; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The year's big drug-industry merger may turn out to be about using marketing muscle to fight fat.

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER; Denise Grady contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: For a prime example of medical screening that has proliferated beyond reason, consider the alarming case of full-body computed tomography scans to detect cancer, cardiovascular disease and other conditions. Narrowly targeted C.T. scans aimed at particular organs are undeniably valuable when used by doctors to pin down a diagnosis in sick patients. But full-body scans to screen healthy individuals for hidden disease have never been shown to be effective, and now there is evidence that the scans may be harmful. A new study finds that the scans impart radiation doses comparable to those received by atomic-bomb survivors in Hiroshima and Nagasaki, causing a small but significant increase in the risk of cancer. Nobody seems quite sure how many Americans get the full-body scans each year. The number is believed to mount into the tens of thousands or conceivably hundreds of thousands. The scans are performed mostly at freestanding clinics that have sprung up to promote the procedure. They can cost more than $1,000 and are seldom covered by insurance, so the clients are presumably affluent or so concerned about hidden disease that they will pay.
docs.abstract: Editorial warns that while narrowly targeted computed tomography scans to detect disease in particular organs are valuable to pin down diagnosis in sick patients, full-body scans to screen healthy people for hidden diseases have never been shown to be effective and expose patients to possibly harmful doses of radiation
docs.snippet: The use of full-body computed tomography scans, which have unproven benefits and may even be harmful, has proliferated beyond reason.

docs.lead_paragraph: To Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Senator Zell Miller, the Democrat from Georgia who delivered a scathing attack on Senator John Kerry at the Republican convention last week, is a rabid opportunist who has become the hate-spewing face of President Bush's re-election campaign. ''He was so frightening that parents took their children away from the television,'' Mr. McAuliffe told reporters in a conference call on Sunday.

headline.main: Steady on the Right, Bush Pitches to the Center

docs.abstract: Pres Bush, campaigning in Parkersburg, W Va, invokes support of Democratic Sen Zell Miller as reason Democrats and independents can feel comfortable voting for him; has used version of same line at every campaign stop since end of Republican convention, bringing rousing cheers from audience; seeks to expand his appeal beyond his conservative base; photo (M)/
docs.snippet: President Bush has an eye toward expanding his appeal beyond his conservative base as the race enters the homestretch.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sharon Alfman, the cook at the little County Seat Diner here, might seem to be a likely John Kerry supporter. She has voted Democratic most of her life. She has no health insurance through the diner, and her husband's insurance ran out after he was on disability for more than a year. But she already knows that she is going to vote for President Bush. Mrs. Alfman, 51, said that if the Democrats could do anything about health insurance, they would have done it under Bill Clinton. Now, she said, the Democrats have ''burned themselves out.'' And like several other people here in this gritty patch of southeastern Ohio, she has already tuned Mr. Kerry out. A Kerry commercial, in which he says his economic plan would provide ''good wages and good benefits,'' came on the overhead television by the kitchen, and no one seemed to notice.

headline.main: In an Old Coal Town, the Old Party Labels Are Faded

docs.snippet: The economy remains the central issue to voters in Ohio, but economic distress does not necessarily mean a vote for the Democrats.

docs.lead_paragraph: If nothing else, John Kerry has revived the public's memory of Herbert Hoover. Again and again, the Democratic candidate has reminded people that George W. Bush has ''the worst record on jobs since Herbert Hoover,'' that Bush is in line to become the first president ''since Hoover'' to preside over a shrinking payroll, that he has ''stood by,'' Hoover-like, while the good honest folk who make up the backbone of the country have lost their jobs. But if Hoover has come to mean a president who fiddled while people went jobless, Bush has been working overtime to repudiate the tag. Everything the president pushes, from limiting jury awards to expanding offshore drilling, he cloaks in the garb of creating jobs, and Bush's advisers have taken to boasting that, thanks to his tax cuts, America has two and a half million more jobs than it otherwise would. The more numerate Kerry, meanwhile, has unveiled a plan to create 10 million jobs; indeed, he has made that plan the centerpiece of his campaign.
docs.abstract: Roger Lowenstein article examines idea that jobs are either lost or created by presidents, citing Sen John Kerry's assertion that Pres Bush has worst record on jobs since Herbert Hoover; says idea that any president is responsible for job creation is myth; poses three problems with scorecard approach to job numbers: most jobs are in private sector, where president is only one of many influences over jobs; labor market does not correspond to presidential cycles; focusing on number of jobs fosters simplistic and illusory sense of presidential power, misdirecting policy toward 'creating' jobs, which are, if anything, outcome of good policy rather than an end; photos (L)
docs.snippet: If nothing else, John Kerry has revived the public's memory of Herbert Hoover. Again and again, the Democratic candidate has reminded people that George W. Bush has ''the worst record on jobs since Herbert Hoover,'' that Bush is in line to become the...

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1972, a night watchman patrolling a hotel-office complex noticed that the basement garage door had been taped open and, attributing this to the carelessness of a maintenance worker earlier that day, peeled the tape off. When, on his next round, he found the door taped open again, he called the police. As a result, citizens of the United States do not enjoy the benefits (or suffer the aggravations) of national health insurance. Or at least that's how Lawrence Malkin and John F. Stacks, the authors of an essay in the anthology ''What Ifs? of American History,'' would have it. The sharp eye of Frank Wills, a security guard at the Watergate building in Washington, is a crucial link in the ''tenuous chain of evidence'' that led to the downfall of President Richard Nixon -- a leader who had, the authors observe, made health care reform a key element of his domestic agenda. What would America's recent history have been like if Wills had been less vigilant? Malkin and Stacks, along with Robert Dallek, James McPherson and other contributors to the anthology (edited by Robert Cowley) take such questions as the jumping-off points for exercises in counterfactuality, the historian's term for speculation about how the past might have unfolded if a particular event had happened otherwise.
docs.abstract: Laura Miller The Last Word column looks at emergence of two forms of historical literature, 'counterfactuality' and 'alternate history'; says former, nonfiction genre, describes likely unfolding of history had a particular event happened otherwise; notes poor reputation of these works among historians, many of whom see them as undermining profession; describes 'alternate history' as akin to science fiction, in which history is rewritten on basis of entirely fictional suppositions; sees alternate history as 'at its best a mournful exercise'; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Among historians, counterfactual scenarios are not very respectable. But alternative history continues to intrigue writers of fiction.

docs.lead_paragraph: Adrienne Abbate and Daniel Benjamin Mackta are to be married today in Stockton, N.J. Rabbi Elliot Levine will officiate at Prallsville Mills, at the Delaware & Raritan Canal State Park. The Rev. Ron D'Angelo, a Catholic priest, will assist in the ceremony. The bride, 30, is a public health program manager for the Medical and Health Research Association of New York City. She graduated from Reed College and received a master's degree in health policy administration from New York University. Her parents, Geraldine and Dr. Anthony D. Abbate, live in Todt Hill, Staten Island. Her father is a urologist in private practice in Brooklyn and the chief urologist at Beth Israel Medical Center in Brooklyn. Her mother is an actress and stage director based in Staten Island.

Fortified by new polls showing him with a clear lead over Senator John Kerry, President Bush talked of economic renewal and tried to blunt Democratic attacks on his economic record as both he and Mr. Kerry campaigned Saturday across northeastern Ohio. ''In order to make sure this economy grows, we've got to make sure we keep your taxes low,'' Mr. Bush said in Kirtland, Ohio, lampooning Mr. Kerry, the Democratic presidential candidate, as a big-government liberal ''who has already promised over $2 trillion of new federal programs.''

headline.main: With Polls on the Move, Bush and Kerry Take Their Economic Message to Ohio

docs.abstract: Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry both campaign in Ohio; Bush criticizes Kerry's proposed spending increases, and Kerry criticizes Bush for raising Medicare premiums; Bush is eager to win state that went for Al Gore in 2000; polls in Ohio show Bush with backing of 52 percent of registered voters against 41 percent for Kerry (M)
docs.snippet: Fortified by new polls showing him with a clear lead over John Kerry, President Bush talked of economic renewal and tried to blunt Democratic attacks on his economic record.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER and RICHARD W. STEVENSON; David M. Halbfinger reported from Steubenville, Ohio, and Richard W. Stevenson from Erie, Pa
